Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Support for the 52nd IEEE/ACM Symposium on Microarchitecture (MICRO)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The IEEE/ACM Symposium on Microarchitecture (MICRO) is a flagship conference in the area of computer architecture. The 2019 annual conference, along with several collocated workshops on related topics, will take place in Columbus, Ohio in October 2019. The conference is an important venue for reporting current research on important topics addressing grand challenges in computing resulting, e.g., from the impending Moore's law slowdown of performance of computing machines. MICRO is a venue where major results of research supported by the program gets presented, discussed, debated and future direction of research are charted. This award will support approximately 30 students by defraying part of their cost for travel and attendance for MICRO 2019. Since attendance to MICRO can be viewed as an integral part of computer systems design education and research in academia, the proposal would go a long way towards supporting workforce development in the important area information technology.

The MICRO conference is attended by leading researchers from technology companies and provides a basis for interaction between academia and industry, thus potentially enhancing technology transfer on problems of current and future societal needs. The grants to students seek to enhance the diversity of the attendees, thus maintain a balance between underrepresented and other groups among the participants supported from the grant. Upon completion of the project, the awardee will submit a report to NSF with details of student experiences and the details of the expenditures towards supporting them to attend the conference and workshops collocated with it.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2019, MICRO was supported by NSF grant 1933772 (PI: Anys Bacha, Student Travel Support for the 52nd IEEE/ACM Symposium on Microarchitecture, 10/1/2019--9/31/2020). Intellectual Merit: 208 students attended MICRO-52. Among them 57 were supported by this grant with a total of $19,530. Among the students, who were supported by this NSF grant, 14 were women or minority. A total of $4,939 was used to support women and students from minority groups. Broader Impact: Students had great experience at the conference. In additional to intellectual stimulation and networking experience, students felt that the conference was inclusive to students. Many students were inspired and touched by Lynn Conway's talk about diversity. Quite a few students attended the Student Research Competition (SRC) and the Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture (CWWMCA). One of the organizers of the CWWMCA workshop was a student who was supported by this grant.

In addition to the official events the conference also facilitated a number of industry-sponsored social events targeted at welcoming underrepresented groups including the AMD Dessert Social Celebrating Diversity and Inclusion and the Under-Represented Minorities and Persons with Disabilities (URMD) Meet-Up & Dinner, sponsored by Microsoft.

 

Below are some testimonials from the travel grant awardees on the conference:

  • “Visiting MICRO gave an opportunity to see the forefront of computer architecture field and talk to people working on the next generation computing systems” Also liked the poster session which presented a great networking opportunity.
  • “This was my first year attending MICRO. Overall, I found it to be the among the most enjoyable conferences I have attended thus far. This year’s keynotes were very interesting and thought provoking.”
  • “I found the interactions with fellow researchers both pleasant and productive. The quality of work being presented acted as a catalyst for very high-level conversations between researchers in both industry and academia. I found everyone to be very enthusiastic. The networking is invaluable: as an active researcher looking for jobs and to continue my research, I found many opportunities for both jobs and collaborations.”
  • “I’m too shy to start a conversation with a stranger. However, things changed after I attended the conference. I met a lot of friendly faculty and students, who shared their opinion and encouraged me to express my idea.”
  • “My experience of MICRO has been unique and fantastic, as I could get a chance to network with amazing computer architects such as Joel Emer from NVIDIA and Pradip Bose from IBM”
  • “I introduced our on-going work with professors at the University of Michigan and NC State University, learned real-world problems that are concerning Intel and AMD engineers, and made friends with graduate students worldwide.”
  • “I think the highlight of the conference was Lynn Conway’s keynote. Her experience spoke to me in a very personal way. Thank you for organizing that keynote! As a female candidate, it meant a lot to me.“
  • “The whole keynote allowed me to look at VLSI and computer architecture with a fresh perspective. It gave me the courage to come up with radically new ideas. I think this will go a long way in my Ph.D. research and personal/professional life thereafter”.
